comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Help, I'm lost!  

Please post a GoogleMapsStreetView, somebody!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: 1894 interactive street map showing tram routes then - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview/?pi=nla.map-rm2686-sd&rgn=...

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06] Photograph taken at what we would now call Central Railway from a location called 'Railway Gates' - before the current station came into use in 1906.  The rubble to the left of the shot would appear to indicate construction work on the future station is well underway.  The tram is an N-class vehicle the first of which No 295 entered service in June 1901. This means that the shot was taken at least six years after the date attributed to it above and possibly closer to the date the new station came into use in 1906  (judging from the rubble). The tram is in it's original livery, and features open drivers' cabins, and looks brand new so it could be on its "maiden run"? So I'd date it circa 1905 in lieu of 1895.

Here's the site today:

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper/5612999818]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] Aha, that explains it, thank you!  Not IN Bondi Junction - it's the old Devonshire Street, looking south-east-ish.  See -

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/2654873676/]

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Note the shrubbery and wall on the left (the southern boundary of the NSW Benevolent Society's asylum) has given way to rubble in the main shot.  Steam trams have given way to electric trams, and the original C-class trams have given way to N-class - the latter being mainly used on the George Street run. This shot of Kaye's shows the scene as it was between the two extremes pictured above. C-class trams dominate.

(As a footnote, I'm now wondering where was the photographer standing to take these shots?)

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/hwmobs/7041622795/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] Thanks! I think the photographers (and Arthur Streeton for his painting) were on top of the Railway Family Hotel, which had a convenient flat roof.  See -

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06/4174797251/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Presumably the old Devonshire Street is on the same alignment as the present Devonshire Street tunnel, so the equivalent GoogleMapsStreetView is maps.google.com.au/maps?q=Sydney,+New+South+Wales&hl=...

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Yes, the tunnel follows the old alignment of Devonshire Street

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: I am dubious that this is Bondi Junction,  there is a substantial hill in the background covered with houses.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mich2009] Thanks Mitch, I think we have established that it is not in Bondi Junction - rather the location is Central Railway in about 1905.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mich2009] It's the Bondi Junction tram - hence the titling of the image I guess. When zooming into the master tiff copy the sign on the tram reads “Bondi Junction”. The sign attached to the station reads "Direct trams for Oxford St and Bondi Junction”.
